Description: Bone carved into the head of an African. The core of the bone has been cleared upwards from neck to be attached to a rod. Possibly served as a stopper. Carved from mammal bone then polished.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), VIth century BC level within sanctuary
Curator's comments: Published by Hogarth (1908, Pl. XXXI.4) as an Archaic ivory, where he compares this with the ivories from Camirus, arguing they are different from those found at Ephesus. ‘The temple of Aphrodite of the IVth (sic, VIth intended) cent. B.C. … A very nice carved bone head of the VIth cent.[ury] B.C., was found there today.’ (Petrie Journal 1885–6,18, 23/12/1885).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WB.01) (Phase 3)
Hogarth D G 1908a / Excavations at Ephesus: the Archaic Artemisia (p. 181, pl. XXXI.4)
